job_title: Store Manager in Silver Spring, MD
pros: I learned a lot working there as far as how to run a business as well as how to develop a team.  I had one of the most successful teams in the company ranking as the top store year over year in two separate markets, one in the Northeast one in the Southeast. I was a paragon winner with the company as well. My most recent DM was very supportive. I genuinely thank them for the opportunity and the knowledge that I acquired while working with them.
cons: Work hours were excessive. To be successful hours worked were borderline slavery. While I willingly worked them to be successful, the week you didn't you were immediately behind. Vacations were almost non existent due to constant visitors from corporate stopping in to do reviews. Holiday weeks were paid 4 days regular 1 holiday and you worked all 5. The facade of the stores looking great when these people stop by versus the reality of the business is polarizing. There were always teams of people and excessive expenditures of payroll thrown into stores prior to their visits. While I understood the need to make an appearance, it was always will always be a backwards way off thinking. Company preaches quality of life for their clients while quality of life for their employees is non-existent. As a "manager" in your average store you will be "managing" a total of one person during your shift, with a total of 10 people at location.  Location open hours will exceed total payroll hours ie Sun-Sat 7am-10pm = 15hrs per day x 7 days x 2 people = 210 hrs which excludes the need to have a person unload deliveries that come in during non opened hours. Your budgeted hours will be approximately 208 hrs. I will only mention that during the month of December that there are extended hours for the stores but no budgeted hours to accommodate. Stores are held to strict shrink targets with little to no control over external theft. Remember 2 people at location, if four people enter to steal there is nothing you can do to stop them. These are facts not personal prejudices.

pros: Flexibility is nice. Pay is okay.

pros: Job security: As one of the largest pharmacy chains in the US, CVS offers job security and stability to its employees. Career advancement opportunities: CVS provides training and development programs for its employees, offering opportunities for career advancement within the company. Competitive pay and benefits: CVS offers competitive pay, health insurance, retirement plans, and other benefits to its employees. Flexible scheduling: CVS offers flexible scheduling to its employees, allowing them to balance their work and personal lives. Learning opportunities: Working in a pharmacy provides opportunities to learn about medications, health conditions, and patient care, which can be valuable for personal and professional growth.
cons: High workload: Pharmacy technicians at CVS often have a high workload, which can be stressful and overwhelming. Fast-paced environment: The pharmacy environment can be fast-paced and demanding, which can be challenging for some individuals. Dealing with difficult customers: Pharmacy technicians may have to deal with difficult or angry customers, which can be stressful. Long hours: Pharmacy technicians may have to work long hours, especially during peak times. Repetitive tasks: Some aspects of the job, such as counting pills or entering data into a computer, can be repetitive and tedious.

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) in Orlando, FL
pros: Working from home. I thought the starting pay of 18.50 was great until the training period was over and I started working at home.
cons: In the position, you are doing everything from explaining benefits to the members, doing prior authorization related work, pharmacy technician responsibilities and even being a therapist for members that are calling just to scream at someone. You have to suck up negativity and don't have time between calls to deal with anxiety or go to the bathroom. You have to meet metrics. Customers scream at you every day and it is not made clear to them that you are the pharmacy, not the insurance company. Very micromanaged. They watch your screen and listen to your microphone at all times. Bathroom breaks don't exist. Everything is counted against you. You cant apply to other positions within the company if you have any corrective actions- even if they are the result of the stressful and toxic position. Excused absences don't exist. I got a point for being 10 minutes late to training due to a horrible accident that the supervisors were already aware of and it was never excused even though it affected half of the training class.

review_title: Micro-managing, unequal pay, unfair reimbursement, unrealistic expectations
pros: Flexibility in the role, prioritize time with family. Benefits are okay, but costly considering this is an insurance company. If you can get approval, education benefits are good.
cons: Micro-managing more than what is reasonable. Ability to promote and grow, but no support or mentorship within the role once you're there. Unrealistic targets and metrics, no consideration for staff individual strengths if not fitting the metric mould. Uneven pay equity. Below industry standard, unequal across roles for similar experience and backgrounds. Uneven pay distribution. Lack of consistent messages from leaders and leaders are not on the same page. When a decision is made and rolled out to staff, anticipate the message changing multiple times and to be delivered with urgent turnaround. Expectations to be available after hours and on call without compensation. Outdated annual review structure. Next to impossible to be recognized for performing above expectations and next to no compensation for those contributions, other than to be expected to do more in coming years.

cons: On 6.1.2022, I was informed that CVS was divesting itself of its home infusion division. Consequently, my job ended on 7.2.2022. While I was saddened to lose my job, I was somewhat relieved to not be in the employ of a corporation which has gone all-in on Woke propaganda. Subsequently, I learned that CVS will subsidize elective terminations of pregnancies for its employees; moreover, CVS will now dispense the abortifacients mifeprestone and misoprestone. I could not work for an employer who profits off of the deaths of innocent (if pre-natal) children any more than I could willingly work for an employer which produced the nerve gas which was used at Auschwitz. "Thou shalt not kill" means just what it says, and I am obliged to obey the Moral Law.

job_title: Senior Manager Analytics in Woonsocket, RI
pros: Comp packages are fantastic, and most people are high performing and willing to collaborate and help each other. The company has a strong balance of short & long term prioritization, and is always looking to innovate and develop the next big thing in healthcare. Most people truly care about their roles and want to make a positive impact in our communities.
cons: In my experience, the work life balance was subpar and it can be a very high stress environment. Leadership is sometimes slow to recognize high performers and those who put in extra work to get the job done with limited resources. Off-cycle comp reviews/promotions are very slow. Typical "large company red tape" is abundant, with access to systems, software, and tools often taking weeks to acquire. Documentation is often non-existent and it can be very difficult to find the right SME to discuss an issue with. Multi-faceted projects lack accountability mechanisms, and teams will not hesitate to pass the buck to others who do not proactively protect their own scope and resources.

review_title: Glad to be working at CVS Health
pros: From day one, I've noticed that CVSH is really committed to diversity and inclusion. There are people from all over the globe which I love. I got involved in colleague groups early on and it really helped me feel comfortable at such a large company. When I've trained people, I always encourage new folks to join these groups to help them acclimate. They are committed to their values, particularly under the new CEO. I've always felt respected and appreciated for my work. They have a way that others can reward other colleagues when demonstrating the core values of the company. We also need to demonstrate how we've lived the core values everyday in our annual reviews. Concerning salary, I currently make above average for project managers based on my location in the country but I've been in my role for about 5 years and have received above average reviews.
cons: I came from a large, regional company to CVS Health and it took me about 6 months to feel really like I understood how the company was structured and who to reach out to solve issues. Sometimes it seems, even now, that within the company, the departments and other business units are very siloed and it takes a lot of time and tenacity to figure out who does what and to know all the departments that exist at the company. There also lots of red tape, so trying to get something done quickly is tricky. Annual raises are not great, even though overall compensation is relatively good.

Our district manager refused to hire a full time manager to replace him for that time period. He would bring in a manager from other stores to “help” once in a while. But the brunt of the work fell to me and another employee. We had two jobs pretty much. Also we were paid over time for the extra hrs but the extra hrs weren’t asked of us but demanded. 

When care pass came around we had daily and weekly quotas to meet for sales of the subscription. We didn’t see much kickback for our work. I was ranked 3rd regionally at one point and sold double that of my colleagues. The only recognition I received was my name mentioned in a conference call and a “good job” from my district manager. The district managers got huge bonuses if their teams did well. The only thing he did for us was buy us doughnuts.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: The ability to work remotely, PTO, education (free IT certification courses).
cons:
The job is constantly placing more responsibility on the CSRs. You are told to assist with: reviewing and explaining member benefits, claims (2 systems), preauthorization, appeals, rewards, provider search, verify providers in 
 3 systems, Medicare Allowed rates, grievances, complaints, and calling 3rd parties for members (billing depts, provider offices). You cannot transfer to claims, all calls must be warm transferred, and calls are dumped with no repercussions.
Supervisors are not properly trained, team members have more knowledge, and favoritism is obvious. It is ok to like someone but if they are bad at their job (or they do not know the work, systems, or desk that you are working), it causes low morale. I would not recommend anyone for this job (unless they want to obtain an online education and get one year of experience to move on). If you are not friends with your manager, you have an abysmal chance to obtain a new role in or out of the department.
The majority of the people I trained with are gone. There is a reason for the bonus (you will not receive the 2nd bonus for 6 mos and must stay one year or you will have to pay it back to Aetna/CVS).

review_title: Review from a high school senior weekend worker
pros: I was able to learn how to work in the service industry, and I got the job in my first interview. Hours worked around my school schedule, and it was close to my house. I liked my coworkers.
cons: The CVS that I worked at was extremely understaffed with one manager and one retail associate working most of the time. CVS is open every single day of the year which means you are usually "encouraged" to work on Christmas, New Year, etc. The self-service system was always shutting down or messing up which forced us to deal with angry customers and broken systems. In general, I think working at CVS ruined my morale and there were many times when I dreaded going to work. Also, the uniform is ugly. On my first day on the job, I was told that most people "don't last 6 months" which can tell you about the employee turnover rate.

pros: You work with some great people across many different departments and business areas. The company has a great mission focusing heavily on the customers/patients.
cons: The annual raises are a joke. They think that giving high raises will offset the fact you have to fight tooth and nail to get higher than a 2-3% raise year after year. And if you work for a smaller team, good luck getting a good raise ever. It is hard being a manager knowing how much you want to give people for a raise/bonus only for upper management to make the final decision. People who don't deserve to be rewarded are rewarded better than those who bust their butts all the time just because of "who they know". The main focus of the company is on the customer/patient. This means they honestly don't care about their employees. The health insurance is extremely expensive, which is depressing considering they literally own Aetna which is a Health Insurance company. They have wellness programs they want you to take advantage of but work you to the bone then reward everyone else around you. And if you get a promotion, don't expect your pay to be on par with others in your area. You could be a manager making the same amount as new hires coming into the department one level below you. Not an incentive to stay with the company. They like to hire external people for more than what they will pay internal people who want to move up the ladder.

The only holidays you have off are 3 major holidays: Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Years. You are paid for other holidays, but you do have to work to get the extra holiday pay and not working is not an option, unless you requested the holiday off months prior. If you take off the day before or after the holiday or even 15 mins late on either of those days, you won’t get the extra holiday pay even if you work the holiday. job_title: Shift Supervisor Rx in Peoria, IL
pros: Benefits, many resources offered to solve work and personal issues, open-door policy, leaders open to hear ideas
cons:
The pay is NOT sustainable, and simply does not equate to the mental/physical/emotional labor. I hate to have to say it, but its simply awful. And it goes for most pharmacy retail. The work you do and the responsibility you take on as a front store manager AND a pharmacy technician - the pay does not even come close to matching the myriad of problems you face every day on the job. When you’re in the pharmacy, more often than not, all of the technicians around you make more money hourly than you do, and you’re responsible for 3x as much? It’s frustrating. What’s most frustrating? No one seems to care. You bring it up to upper management and get smoke blown in your face. It’s offensive. 

You close out the business day, as you leave you solely are responsible for anything that may happen as you lock up the store as far as compliance related to the standards of the law, the company, the board of pharmacy, the government, the health department, etc are concerned… you get home, and eat Triscuit crackers because you can’t afford a meal.

pros: They pay well for the area that I’m in. That’s it, though.
cons: The environment is extremely stressful. The other employees in the pharmacy are argumentative and awful at customer service. They make cashiers do the same work as pharmacy techs without them getting the pay for it. None of your work is recognized. Even if you stay late, come in early, come in on your days off, and work through your lunches, they still get angry with you if you may be running late because of a doctor/vet appointment. Very unprofessional environment.

Voluntarily going unpaid as an option would work slightly better. Especially since not everyone can qualify for reasonable accommodation. On top of that, we were all promised job security, and had a huge new hire ramp up last year & we were promised job security. Now a good percentage of people are about to be laid off next month since work has been continuously slow. YET they still have constant job posting offering sign on bonuses and don’t want to talk much about it with us or encourage us to apply within.

job_title: Shift Supervisor Rx in Monroe, NC
pros:
They try to have relatively competitive wages
They are generally flexible with hours
Benefits aren't terrible or too expensive
In my experience, they try to move people up
cons: When April comes, and a few months before, the big wigs bonuses are coming up and the first thing to get cut, ALWAYS, is hours. It increases stress tenfold, especially in the pharmacy. Everybody gets behind, customers hate the wait, and you're already running a skeleton crew so if someone calls out, "Oh well, work harder, " because if you don't, the District Leader will still have to come down and complain about numbers or customer scores. My current store manager has been threatened to be fired over the course of a month for being, collectively, about 100 hours over. Just to give a bit of perspective, she's had to open the store and be by herself until shift change at 3 to 5 in the afternoon more than a couple times each week. One wouldn't think that a company that made a $116,000,000,000 (One-hundred and sixteen BILLION) profit last year would really give so little hours that only one person can work for 8 hours or care about an extra $2000, and that's overestimating, over the course of a month to keep their employees/customers a lot happier. I was even told by one of the higher ups that it doesn't have to do with morality or logic in the slightest, it's all about the money.

review_title: A good place to learn how to be an efficient worker, if you are willing to stomach it
pros:
In my 13 year span with CVS I must admit they are always evolving and staying on top of the always changing healthcare field. 
If your work ethic isn't great, and you're willing to take criticism and tough out some stressful times, CVS can potentially mold anyone into a solid worker that can carry over to new careers.
The union for technician is so, so.... But at least there's a union
cons:
It can get rough, especially if your superiors are not up to par.
CVS owns both Caremark (rx insurance) and Aetna (medical insurance), yet they offer their employees embarrassing healthcare bundles that most employees refuse if they have the option of going with their spouse's healthcare plan.
CVS always adds software to implement programs they create.... But the hardware stays the same...... I've heard a computer tech who does maintenance on all hardware say that the phone systems and registers are the same as the ones he worked with at Macy's back in the mid 90s

CVS = MICRO-MANGMENT

pros:
Customers were easy to please and most of them were actually fun to help. 

Learned about products I never knew existed 

Time ran really fast during the day and somewhat night
cons:
Training was really awful. The manager was really comfortable to talk to, except I was placed with a worker who’s father had died 3 months ago combined with a horrible attitude and negative outlook on life. 

Frustration came easy to her especially when I asked her questions with an instant, unwelcoming reply of “I don’t know.” I got tired of it eventually. I stopped asking her questions and was pretty much on my own unless the manager was around; the I’d ask as much as possible. Surprisingly, the computer system and passport sections were easy to get used to, which leads me to one exception. The money orders. 

Every single shift, none of the managers NEVER counted the money with me. They never told me to stay after, either in order to present after the money is counted. Henceforth, they called me in one day saying I was missing $100. I talked about it with some coworkers and they said it happened to someone else and it was fine, so I shrugged it off.

Then it happened again. So I thought someone was stealing from me, but they never counted the money in front of me still….everything was super shady

review_title: Health insurance company offers employees apps instead of health care
pros: It's offices are in Burlington, outside the busy rush of Boston with plenty of free parking and near a bunch of GREAT new restaurants.
cons:
1) 90 day wait on receiving any benefits
2) Aetna (owned by CVS) offers the WORST insurance options we've ever experienced. Very high deductible HMO. Top of the line plan for a family of 4 costs about $17K in premiums with an $11,600 deductible — we almost reached our deductible in the first year — a full gross income this costs!!
3) Aetna does not cover many typical medical offerings like acupuncture, physical therapy and a wide array of specialized care. Instead they offer access to apps on your phone — 'cause they care...
4) Must go in to the office a minimum of 2 days per week, regardless of efficiency, cost or need. 
5) When hired they heavily pushed their progressive Work / Life balance which has completely disappeared.
6) Most high level executives are currently running for the exits (first quarter 2022). Serious amount of turnover where no one really knows what's going on.
7) If you enjoy sitting in back to back meetings or on Zoom calls for the entire day (8:30 - 6:00) and then doing all your work outside those hours, this is definitely the job for you!

review_title: Great place to start pharmacy career!
pros: Lot of flexibility for your work schedule.
cons: There were some really rude coworkers at my location.

pros:
I love the job itself. It has taught me one of my deepest interests which is pharmaceutical sciences. 

The pay and schedule are great. I am able to work in as many or as few hours i want. 

I've been able to really connect with some great customers and co workers.
cons:
Store and district level management are very demanding. They don't understand that we deal with stressful, understaffed jobs that, honestly, should be paid several dollars more per hour.  They just recently wrote up a coworker of mine for calling off, for the first time in 6 months. They also advised the employee that they had accumulated enough attendance points for termination, but that "as a favor" they would knock it down to just a written and documented formal warning, which is the step below termination. 
This employee had called off for legitimate reasons: for having been diagnosed COVID+, for calling off due to snow/ice storms in the winter, for not feeling well (this employee is chronically ill and management knows it I believe). 
I saw this and asked my manager about it. They replied that even though there had been valid excuses for each absence, the employee was still responsible for the accompanying shift. I figured "good. Why should anyone place a job over their health and well being?"
I'm now trying to find another job in order to leave. If I stay around, they'll eventually treat me the same.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: If you enjoy client-facing roles you get plenty of interaction with patients and customers of CVS.
cons:
If you need to use the restroom you will need to hold it. Lunch is set for 30 minutes? You'll get more like 15-20. If this sounds appealing to you while working at the same rate that chick-fil-a pays their employees to handle insurance adjudication, COVID-19 Testing, and a surplus of prescriptions that are behind. This is the role for you.

There were weekends we were reaching out to our DL for help just to never hear back. 30+ vaccinations for the pharmacist and back to back testing for the technician when we were the only two in the store. Drive-thru line around the building, people stuck in it waiting for prescriptions as testing was done in front of them.

This was not worth the stress or the $12.70 an hour. They have not increased their pay despite the strain on the profession due to COVID-19. I spent more time COVID-19 Testing people than most tasks on days when I had no additional pay for it.

I also recommend looking up Ashleigh Anderson. CVS can post about how they support Women all they please, while they let one of their own who was supposed to be a valued pharmacist die on the clock in their pharmacy.

review_title: Cvs replaces employees with self checkout
pros: Literally nothing, but I have to enter 5 words in order to submit this review.
cons: Our CVS store had self checkouts installed. We are told not to ring the customers up behind the registers and to have the customers use the self checkouts only. They cut the store hours and replaced employees with the self checkouts. I have gone 2 weeks so far being completely cut off the schedule due to this change, and I have worked for this company for more than 10 years. They schedule a supervisor to work alone and force the supervisor to make the customers use the self checkout so that they can get their assigned work done. The upper management gets reports on the usage of the self checkouts. If the self checkout is not used enough they threaten to write the employees up. They also force the employees to sign customers up for carepass. If you don’t get enough customers to sign up for carepass they will write you up. Trust me, you do not want to work here.

pros: I've learned a lot at CVS from team building to workflow and operations, and even HR responsibilities. However, expect this company to work you to the ground until you can no longer take it anymore. Pharmacists work long hours 12 hour shifts with no lunch break. It's 12 hours of straight work where you are on your feet running to station to station to help customers (who by the way are extremely unhinged due to the current times/pandemic). I've left CVS many times due to burnout but keep coming back. The expectation is to be disrespected by customers and management alike. No one is safe in the company. We are extremely undervalued and barked at by upper management who have no pharmacy experience whatsoever. Retail pharmacy services is equivalent to Burger King services. Yes, you can have it your way and within 15 minutes -__- Jokes aside, I'm a month in from being rehired and I've already had enough / ready to call it quits. CVS C-level execs if you're reading this it's not too late. Be the change you want to see in the retail pharmacy world. You have the power to make retail pharmacy great again!
cons: Overworked and undervalued. Pharmacists are walking liabilities due to unreasonable demands and lack of support personnel.

pros:
If you put in your time, and simply try, they will appreciate you. 

Management was kind and understanding for the most part. Even if they didn't like you much. I found things to be fair overall.

Instant 401k vesting, PTO was solid for the area. Work from home is a benefit the company actively desires employees to consider. Paycheck is steady as a rock. They do offer long term careers if you're cool with dealing with customers and honestly they do promote internally. They don't look poorly on internal candidates. They'll treat you right, unless you wind up in the wrong department, so you'll need to be aware.

Many good things. Just work hard. They are better than most employers out there. Take the good with the bad. Most managers do want you to succeed and in turn you'll want them to succeed. Fond memories of managers I thought would be hell that turned out to be the sweetest people I'd ever worked with. 

Pro LGBT, and pro minority in general. Still think it's cool the manager I had been most afraid of turned out to be a lesbian who played video games and I absolutely loved working with her before I wound up in escalations. Just because someone has a reputation doesn't mean they'll wind up interacting with you negatively at all.

Good people run the place. They do provide safety for you, even if the customers can be rough.
cons:
The management in my most recent department was facing increasing strictures and I lost faith in their ability to treat anyone like a human being. Left of my own accord after reporting concerns about management to the executive levels. Nothing management does will ever stick to management, period--nothing they say or do to an hourly employee will ever matter. Management will defend management or gaslight you as an "emotions based person." Highly concerning. 

Hateful & juvenile in a siloed way I think was intentionally cultivated. Again, the rest of management isn't like this or at least doesn't show it to employees. Left before the rot could get to me. Still think overall the PBM side of the company is pretty good to work for and I have fond memories overall until recent events.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: Paid time off is granted upfront and does not need to be accrued. Entry wage is a fair living wage for a first job. They also gave yearly cost of living increases. My training was good. It was a good first job and after 2 years I was ready to move on to a new company in a new role.
cons: For a health care company I expected and was hoping to have affordable health care as a benefit. They offer high deductible plans with high yearly premium rates. They do contribute some to an HSA but overall it proved to be the most expensive health care I have ever had.

review_title: Nows not the time to join CVS
pros: In June they’ll be raising minimum wage for cashiers but keep in mind most other positions will likely get screwed over. The insurance through Aetna, since they own them, is actually pretty great. Employee discount isn’t bad and if you watch enough extreme couponers you’ll be turn into a very savvy shopper.
cons: This company was perfectly fine to work with two or three years ago, but in the past year they have taken away so many hours it’s borderline unsafe to work there. They look the other way when you’re required to work all by yourself several hours of the week, and not only do they not care about your safety, don’t care that you have any backup even though the store offers several services. Since the introduction of Carepass and the self checkouts, employees are leaving, and stores are closing. Don’t join the work force they’re desperately hiring let them go down.

pros: No experience needed and will train you.
cons: There is no room for growth, cvs health owns Aetna and still give their employees trash medical benefits. Everyday is a new rule. CVS just started closing the pharmacy for lunch which is great but its only so they can make sure you DONT get paid for 30 minutes so they are able to save as much money as they can. District leaders don't really care about what the employees go through or how heavy our work load maybe , they just decrease hours given and only care about numbers. CVS wants their employees to work like robots with very little at home work like balance. Corporate will decrease store hours and tell you to use vacation time to make up the rest. During the pandemic we struggled with staffing and would tell stores to hire as much as they can, now those same people have to drive around from store to store just to keep afloat.
